The **economy of Cameroon** was one of the most prosperous in Africa for a
quarter of a century after independence. The drop in commodity prices for its
principal exports – petroleum, cocoa, coffee, and cotton – in the mid-1980s,
combined with an overvalued currency and economic mismanagement, led to a
decade-long recession. Real per capita GDP fell by more than 60% from 1986 to
1994. The current account and fiscal deficits widened, and foreign debt grew.
Yet because of its oil reserves and favorable agricultural conditions,
Cameroon still has one of the best-endowed primary commodity economies in sub-
Saharan Africa.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Cameroon was among the most prosperous in Africa for approximately twenty-five years following its independence.
• The principal exports of Cameroon included petroleum, cocoa, coffee, and cotton.
• In the mid-1980s, Cameroon experienced a significant decline in commodity prices for these key exports.
• Contributing to economic decline was an overvalued currency and widespread economic mismanagement.
• The economic downturn resulted in a recession that lasted for about ten years.
• Between 1986 and 1994, Cameroon’s real per capita GDP decreased by more than 60%.
• During this period, Cameroon’s current account and fiscal deficits widened substantially.
• The country’s foreign debt increased as a consequence of economic deterioration.
• Despite these challenges, Cameroon maintained a strong endowment of primary commodities due to its oil reserves and favorable agricultural conditions.
• As a result, Cameroon remains one of the best-endowed primary commodity economies in sub-Saharan Africa.
• In 2018, Cameroon produced approximately 5 million tons of cassava, ranking as the 13th largest producer globally.
• The country produced about 3.9 million tonnes of plantain, making it the 3rd largest producer in the world, behind Congo and Ghana.
• Cameroon’s palm oil production reached approximately 2.6 million tons, placing it as the 7th largest producer worldwide.
• The nation produced around 2.3 million tons of maize.
• Taro production was approximately 1.9 million tons, ranking Cameroon as the 3rd largest producer globally, second only to Nigeria and China.
• The country produced about 1.4 million tons of sorghum.
• Banana production was approximately 1.2 million tons.
• Sugarcane output also reached about 1.2 million tons.
• Cameroon produced roughly 1 million tons of tomatoes, ranking as the 19th largest producer in the world.
• Yam production was approximately 674,000 tonnes, making Cameroon the 7th largest producer globally.
• Peanut production was around 594,000 tons.
• The country produced about 410,000 tons of sweet potato.
• Bean production was approximately 402,000 tons.
• Rice output was about 332,000 tons.
• Pineapple production reached roughly 310,000 tons.
• Cameroon produced approximately 307,000 tons of cocoa, ranking as the 5th largest producer worldwide, after Ivory Coast, Ghana, Indonesia, and Nigeria.
• Potato production was around 302,000 tons.
• Onion output was approximately 301,000 tons.
• Cotton production was about 249,000 tons.
• In addition to these major crops, Cameroon produced smaller quantities of other agricultural products, including coffee with 33,000 tons and natural rubber with 55,000 tons.

text:
Cameroon's financial system is the largest in the CEMAC region. Access to
financial services is limited, particularly for SMEs. Aside from a traditional
tendency for banks to prefer dealing with large, established companies,
determining factors are also found in interest rates for loans to SMEs being
capped at 15 percent and being heavily taxed. As of 2006, bank loans to SMEs
hardly reached 15 percent of total outstanding loans (Molua, 2002).

Less than 5 percent of Cameroonians have access to a bank account. While the
microfinance sector is consequently becoming increasingly important, its
development is hampered by a loose regulatory and supervisory framework for
microfinance institutions (MFIs). The banking sector is highly concentrated
and dominated by foreign commercial banks. 6 out of the 11 largest commercial
banks are foreign-owned, and the three largest banks hold more than 50 percent
of total financial system assets. While foreign banks generally display good
solvency ratios, small domestic banks are in a much weaker position. Their
capitalization is well below the average of banks in the CEMAC region and
their profits are close to 2 percent, compared to 20 percent for foreign banks
in the country. This is partially explained by the high levels of non-
performing loans, which reached 12 percent in 2007, leading to most banks
holding large amounts of excess reserves as a percentage of deposits and large
levels of unutilized liquidity.

In 2018, Cameroon's financial system is being requested by the International
Monetary Fund (IMF) to increase its tax base to cover the losses from the
North-West and South-West Cameroon's regions instabilities, the loss of oil
revenue, the failure to deliver on port facilities, and the decline in oil
production from mature oil fields.
openai_summarised_points: • Cameroon's financial system is the largest within the CEMAC (Economic and Monetary Community of Central Africa) region.
• Access to financial services in Cameroon remains limited, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).
• Banks in Cameroon tend to prefer dealing with large, established companies, reflecting a traditional banking tendency.
• Loan interest rates for SMEs are capped at 15 percent and are subject to heavy taxation, which influences lending practices.
• As of 2006, bank loans to SMEs constituted less than 15 percent of the total outstanding loans, indicating limited credit allocation to small businesses (Molua, 2002).
• Less than 5 percent of the Cameroonian population has access to a bank account, highlighting low financial inclusion.

• The microfinance sector is gaining importance due to limited traditional banking access, but its development is hindered by a lax regulatory and supervisory framework for microfinance institutions (MFIs).
• The banking sector in Cameroon is highly concentrated and predominantly dominated by foreign commercial banks.
• Six out of the eleven largest commercial banks in Cameroon are foreign-owned.
• The three largest banks in Cameroon hold more than 50 percent of the total assets within the financial system.
• Foreign banks in Cameroon generally maintain good solvency ratios, indicating financial stability.
• Domestic banks are relatively weaker, with capitalization levels below the regional average for banks in the CEMAC zone.
• Domestic banks' profits are approximately 2 percent, significantly lower than the 20 percent profit margin of foreign banks operating in Cameroon.
• The high levels of non-performing loans, which reached 12 percent in 2007, contribute to the financial fragility of domestic banks.
• Due to non-performing loans, most banks hold large amounts of excess reserves relative to deposits and exhibit high levels of unutilized liquidity.
• In 2018, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommended that Cameroon increase its tax base to offset financial losses caused by regional instabilities in the North-West and South-West regions.

• Additional economic challenges include the loss of oil revenue, failure to develop port facilities, and a decline in oil production from mature oil fields, all impacting the financial system's stability and revenue.

text:
Cameroon became an oil-producing country in 1977. Claiming to want to make
reserves for difficult times, the authorities manage "off-budget" oil revenues
in total opacity (the funds are placed in Paris, Switzerland and New York
accounts). Several billion dollars are thus diverted to the benefit of oil
companies and regime officials. The influence of France and its 9,000
nationals in Cameroon remains considerable. African Affairs magazine noted in
the early 1980s that they "continue to dominate almost all key sectors of the
economy, much as they did before independence. French nationals control 55% of
the modern sector of the Cameroonian economy and their control over the
banking system is total.

Recent signs, however, are encouraging. As of March 1998, Cameroon's fifth IMF
program – a 3-year enhanced structural adjustment program approved in August
1997 – is on track. Cameroon has rescheduled its Paris Club debt at favorable
terms. GDP has grown by about 5% a year beginning in 1995. There is cautious
optimism that Cameroon is emerging from its long period of economic hardship.

Cameroonian exports in 2006

The Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) signed recently by the IMF
and Government of Cameroon calls for greater macroeconomic planning and
financial accountability; privatization of most of Cameroon's nearly 100
remaining non-financial parastatal enterprises; elimination of state marketing
board monopolies on the export of cocoa, certain coffees, and cotton;
privatization and price competition in the banking sector; implementation of
the 1992 labor code; a vastly improved judicial system; and political
liberalization to boost investment.

France is Cameroon's main trading partner and source of private investment and
foreign aid. Cameroon has an investment guaranty agreement and a bilateral
accord with the United States. USA investment in Cameroon is about $1 million,
most of it in the oil sector. Inflation has been brought back under control.
Cameroon aims at becoming emerging by 2035.

The government embarked upon a series of economic reform programs supported by
the World Bank and International Monetary Fund (IMF) beginning in the late
1980s. Many of these measures have been painful; the government slashed civil
service salaries by 65% in 1993. The CFA franc – the common currency of
Cameroon and 13 other African states – was devalued by 50% in January 1994.
The government failed to meet the conditions of the first four IMF programs.

openai_summarised_points: • Cameroon became an oil-producing country in 1977, marking a significant shift in its resource base and economic structure.

• The authorities manage "off-budget" oil revenues with total opacity, placing the funds in accounts located in Paris, Switzerland, and New York, leading to several billion dollars being diverted to benefit oil companies and regime officials.

• The influence of France in Cameroon remains substantial, with French nationals continuing to dominate key sectors of the economy, as noted by African Affairs magazine in the early 1980s, which stated that they "continue to dominate almost all key sectors of the economy, much as they did before independence."
• French nationals control 55% of the modern sector of the Cameroonian economy, and their control over the banking system is described as total.
• As of March 1998, Cameroon’s fifth IMF program—a 3-year enhanced structural adjustment program approved in August 1997—is on track, indicating progress in economic reforms.
• Cameroon successfully rescheduled its Paris Club debt under favorable terms, improving its debt sustainability.
• From 1995 onward, Cameroon’s GDP has grown at an average rate of about 5% annually, signaling cautious optimism about emerging from a prolonged period of economic hardship.

• The IMF’s Enhanced Structural Adjustment Facility (ESAF) signed with Cameroon emphasizes greater macroeconomic planning, financial accountability, privatization of nearly 100 remaining non-financial parastatal enterprises, and elimination of state marketing board monopolies on exports of cocoa, certain coffees, and cotton.

• The program also calls for privatization and increased price competition in the banking sector, implementation of the 1992 labor code, judicial system improvements, and political liberalization to attract investment.
• France remains Cameroon’s main trading partner, primary source of private investment, and foreign aid provider.
• Cameroon has an investment guaranty agreement and bilateral accords with the United States, with U.S. investment estimated at about $1 million, mostly in the oil sector.
• Inflation in Cameroon has been brought under control, contributing to macroeconomic stability.
• The country aims to become an emerging economy by 2035.

• Beginning in the late 1980s, Cameroon embarked on a series of economic reforms supported by the World Bank and IMF, which involved painful measures such as a 65% cut in civil service salaries in 1993.
• The CFA franc, shared with 13 other African states, was devalued by 50% in January 1994, as part of stabilization efforts.
• Cameroon failed to meet the conditions of the first four IMF programs, indicating challenges in implementing reforms.

• The gross domestic product (GDP) at market prices, estimated by the IMF in millions of Central African CFA Francs, shows a steady growth trend from 1980 to 2022, with notable increases over the decades.
• Specific GDP figures in Central African CFA Francs and US Dollars (at exchange rates) for selected years include:
• 2010: 57,200,000 million CFAF (~27.53 USD nominal), with GDP in US$ PPP at 57.2 billion and per capita at 2,814 US$ PPP.
• 2020: GDP of 102.7 billion USD, with a growth rate of 0.5% and inflation at 2.5%.
• 2022: GDP of 123.3 billion USD, with a growth rate of 3.8% and inflation at 4.6%.
• From 1980 to 2022, Cameroon’s GDP in US$ PPP increased from 11.1 billion (1980) to 123.3 billion (2022), with GDP per capita rising from 1,263 US$ PPP to 4,419 US$ PPP.
• The real GDP growth rate fluctuated, with notable declines during the late 1980s and early 1990s, but generally trending upward in recent years.
• Inflation remained below 5% from 2003 onward, with occasional brief increases, such as 12.7% in 1994, and stabilized around low single digits in the 2010s and early 2020s.
• Government debt as a percentage of GDP decreased from 68% in 1998 and 1999 to 14% in 2007, then gradually increased to 47% by 2022.
